definition: Automated City Register Information System - allows you to search property records and view document images for Manhattan, Queens, Bronx, and Brooklyn from 1966 to the present.
Construction or renovation work done before 7:00 AM or after 6:00 PM on weekdays, or anytime on weekends. Requires an After Hours Variance (AHV) permit.

A construction project that results in a new Certificate of Occupancy. Types: Type I (major CO changes like use conversions), Type II (multiple trades without use change), Type III (minor work like curb cuts). Work that doesn't trigger a new CO is classified as renovation instead.
A residential building containing four or more dwelling units, each with access to above-grade common halls, stairs, elevators, and yards.
A licensed professional like an architect or engineer who files construction plans with the city and ensures work meets all laws and codes.
A licensed professional who designs buildings and oversees construction projects. They create drawings, specifications, and ensure designs meet building codes.

A hazardous building material once commonly used for insulation and fireproofing. Inhaling fibers can cause lung cancer, mesothelioma, and asbestosis (effects appear 10-50 years later). Intact asbestos presents minimal danger, but disruption during renovations significantly increases hazards.
[AI-DRAFT] A detailed review of construction documents by DOB to verify code compliance. Can result in objections that must be addressed before approval.
[AI-DRAFT] A financial institution that provides construction loans and mortgages for building projects. Banks underwrite loans based on project risk.
A floor level partly or fully below ground. In NYC, 'basement' often refers to illegal basement apartments that don't meet code requirements.
Buildings Information System - NYC Department of Buildings' free online tool where anyone can check property details, permits, violations, and complaints.
The official document that confirms a violation has been fixed and stops the accumulation of penalties for unresolved violations.

A Certificate of Occupancy (CO) is like a birth certificate for a building. It officially records how the building can be used and verifies compliance with local codes and zoning laws. Required before a building can be legally occupied.
[AI-DRAFT] A modification to a construction contract that changes the scope, cost, or timeline of a project. Often results from unforeseen conditions.
Categories used to classify DOB violations by severity: Class A (most dangerous, must be fixed immediately), Class B (hazardous), Class C (non-hazardous).
[AI-DRAFT] A DOB employee who processes permit applications, maintains records, and handles administrative tasks at the Department of Buildings.
A report filed with NYC agencies about building code issues, unsafe conditions, or illegal construction. Complaints may trigger inspections.
A professional hired to perform construction, repair, remodeling, or additions to buildings. In NYC, contractors working on residences must be licensed.

NYC Department of Environmental Protection manages the city's water supply, sewers, wastewater treatment, and environmental rules. DEP can issue violations and fines for homeowner-caused issues like leaks or sewer backups that strain infrastructure.

Department of Buildings - NYC agency that reviews and approves building plans and permits, enforces building codes, licenses construction professionals, conducts inspections, and manages building emergencies. Failing to follow DOB requirements can result in violations, fines, stop-work orders, or eviction.

An online system created by the NYC Department of Buildings to make it easier for homeowners and professionals to handle building permits, inspections, and construction-related paperwork. Users can track permits, schedule inspections, and submit documents online.
[AI-DRAFT] Official authorization required before tearing down a building or portion of a building. Involves safety reviews and environmental assessments.

Environmental Control Board - a division of NYC's Office of Administrative Trials and Hearings (OATH) that holds hearings on violations issued by city agencies like DOB, DEP, and FDNY. ECB determines responsibility for violations and assesses fines as an independent tribunal.
An online platform that property owners, architects, engineers, and contractors use to submit and manage building permit applications and other related filings in NYC.
[AI-DRAFT] A licensed professional who designs structural, mechanical, electrical, or plumbing systems for buildings. Works with architects to ensure buildings are safe and functional.

A DOB-registered filing representative (NYC expeditor) who streamlines building permit processes. They submit applications, present projects to DOB clerks and examiners, address objections, and coordinate approvals. With decades of experience, expeditors specialize in accelerating DOB and other agency approvals.
[AI-DRAFT] The exterior face of a building, typically the front. Facade work includes repairs, cleaning, and decorative improvements to the building's exterior.
Not correcting a cited issue by the specified deadline and/or failing to certify the correction to the issuing agency. Results in escalating penalties.
Fire Department of New York - agency responsible for fire safety inspections, sprinkler and fire alarm permits, and fire code compliance.
[AI-DRAFT] The formal submission of construction documents, plans, and applications to DOB for review and approval. Different filing types include new building, alteration, and demolition.
[AI-DRAFT] The last stage of DOB review before a permit is issued or a certificate of occupancy is granted. Includes final document review and inspections.
[AI-DRAFT] Construction that incorporates environmentally sustainable practices including energy efficiency, renewable materials, and reduced environmental impact.

Department of Housing Preservation and Development - NYC agency that issues violations when properties violate housing code standards, covering problems like broken equipment, leaks, poor hygiene, or pest issues.
aliases: Department of Housing Preservation and Development

definition: [AI-DRAFT] Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning - the mechanical systems that control a building's climate. HVAC work often requires permits and inspections.
The DOB term for occurrences caused by construction or demolition activity that may or may not result in injury, such as structural failures, equipment collapses, or near-misses.
An official examination of construction work by DOB, FDNY, or other agencies to verify compliance with approved plans and building codes.

NYC inspectors check homes to keep them safe and ensure they follow city rules. DOB inspectors oversee construction, zoning, and major repairs. HPD housing inspectors handle rentals for heat, hot water, pests, leaks, lead paint, and smoke detectors. Both enforce codes through scheduled or surprise visits.
[AI-DRAFT] An individual or organization that provides capital for construction projects in exchange for ownership stake or expected returns.
Limited Alteration Application - a DOB filing method used for minor alterations with a defined scope of work, such as correcting plumbing violations.
[AI-DRAFT] Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design - a green building certification program that rates buildings on sustainability, energy efficiency, and environmental impact.
aliases: Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design

definition: Licensed Master Plumber - a qualified professional required to perform plumbing work and submit necessary paperwork to the DOB in NYC.
[AI-DRAFT] Borrowed money used to finance construction projects. Construction loans are typically short-term and convert to mortgages upon project completion.
[AI-DRAFT] The non-structural systems in a building including HVAC, plumbing, electrical, and fire protection. Mechanical work requires specialized permits.
[AI-DRAFT] A building or project that combines residential, commercial, and/or industrial uses. Common in urban areas to maximize land use efficiency.
[AI-DRAFT] The process of discussing terms between parties in a construction project, such as contract terms, change orders, or dispute resolution.
An official document sent by a NYC agency to inform a property owner that something on their property might not follow local building or safety codes.
Office of Administrative Trials and Hearings - NYC's central, independent administrative law court that handles hearings for violations issued by city agencies.
aliases: Office of Administrative Trials and Hearings

definition: [AI-DRAFT] The property owner who initiates and funds a construction project. The owner hires professionals like architects, engineers, and contractors.
[AI-DRAFT] Financial fines imposed for building code violations. Penalties can accumulate daily until violations are corrected and certified.

Official authorization from NYC's Department of Buildings allowing construction, alteration, demolition, or related work. Permits ensure compliance with building codes, safety regulations, and zoning laws. Types include New Building, Alteration (Types 1-3), and specialized permits.
[AI-DRAFT] The DOB review process where examiners check construction plans for code compliance. Can result in objections that must be resolved before approval.
[AI-DRAFT] A DOB employee who reviews construction plans and drawings to ensure they comply with building codes before issuing permits.
[AI-DRAFT] The water supply and drainage systems in a building. Plumbing work requires permits and must be performed by licensed plumbers.
[AI-DRAFT] A faster DOB approval path where a licensed professional certifies that plans comply with code, bypassing standard plan examination. Subject to audit.
[AI-DRAFT] The professional responsible for overseeing a construction project from start to finish, coordinating between owner, designers, and contractors.
Plan/Work Application - the primary DOB application form for getting approval of construction plans and work. Required for most building projects.

Any improvement, modification, or repair work done to a property - interiors, exteriors, structural elements, or building systems. Must comply with NYC building codes and typically requires permits. Illegal renovation = work done without proper documentation and permits.
[AI-DRAFT] Upgrading an existing building with new or improved systems, such as energy-efficient equipment or seismic improvements.
[AI-DRAFT] The defined extent of work in a construction project, including what will be built, modified, or demolished. Changes to scope affect cost and timeline.
[AI-DRAFT] Structural modifications to make existing buildings more resistant to earthquakes. Required in some areas for certain building types.
[AI-DRAFT] Fire suppression systems that automatically release water when fire is detected. Sprinkler installation requires FDNY permits and inspections.
Stop Work Order - an order issued when construction or repair work must be stopped because inspectors found unsafe conditions or work that could be dangerous.
[AI-DRAFT] The process by which a bank or lender evaluates a construction project's risk and determines loan terms, amount, and interest rate.
Work or installations completed without proper authorization or permits from NYC authorities. Unpermitted work can result in violations and fines.
A structure that poses risks to occupants or the public due to structural defects, fire hazards, or other dangerous conditions.
[AI-DRAFT] An exception to zoning rules granted by the city allowing a property to be used in a way not normally permitted. Requires approval from the Board of Standards and Appeals.

Notices issued by NYC agencies such as DOB, ECB, and HPD for non-compliance with building, housing, safety, or environmental codes. Violation classes: Class A (most dangerous - fix immediately), Class B (hazardous - 30 days), Class C (non-hazardous - 90 days).
[AI-DRAFT] Local laws that regulate how land and buildings can be used in different areas. Zoning determines what can be built, how tall, and what uses are permitted.
Expert advice and services related to understanding and complying with the NYC Zoning Resolution and other building codes.

Temporary elevated platforms for construction work. NYC requires permits for supported scaffolds over 40 feet and for sidewalk sheds. 2025 standards require 12 feet minimum height and adequate lighting.
Facade Inspection Safety Program - NYC requirement for buildings over 6 stories to have their facades inspected every 5 years by a licensed professional.
Converting a space to residential use without proper permits or in violation of zoning laws. Common examples include converting basements, attics, or commercial spaces to apartments.
A fungal growth that can develop in damp building conditions. Mold remediation may require professional handling and can be cited as an HPD violation.
Horizontal structural members that support floors and ceilings. Joists transfer loads to beams and walls. Common in wood-frame and steel construction.
A construction technique to strengthen or deepen existing foundations. Required when excavating near existing buildings or when foundations are inadequate.
A DOB enforcement mechanism allowing immediate stop-work orders and penalties for the most serious safety violations on construction sites.
Converting attic space into habitable living area. Requires proper permits, egress windows, ceiling height, and may require structural reinforcement.
A property requiring significant repairs or renovations before occupancy. Often purchased below market value with intent to renovate.
Violations issued by FDNY for non-compliance with fire safety regulations including blocked exits, missing fire extinguishers, or faulty sprinkler systems.
Letter of Completion - a document issued by DOB confirming that construction work has been completed in accordance with approved plans and permits.

Records containing Block & Lot information, existing legal plans, violation copies, sales history, parcel number, title changes, liens, square footage, year built, permits, zoning, and historical records of repairs and alterations.

Describes the use or occupancy of a building or zoning district type. Becomes relevant when DOB rules, permits, violations, or exemptions depend on whether a building is classified as residential rather than commercial or industrial.

Building foundations rest on solid ground and spread the building's weight within safe limits for the soil. Must comply with NYC Building Code requiring proper soil support, adequate depth (typically 4 feet below frost line), and detailed geotechnical planning.

New York City Housing Authority - the largest public housing authority in North America, managing affordable housing for over 400,000 residents across 335 developments. Also administers Section 8 vouchers for 235,000+ people in private rentals.

Multiple Dwelling Law - NY State statute defining 'private dwellings' (1-2 families) and 'multiple dwellings' (3+ families). Class A = permanent residence (30+ days), Class B = transient occupancy (hotels). Imposes rules on design, safety, fire protection, and occupancy.

Real Estate Board of New York - leading trade association founded in 1896 representing property owners, builders, managers, investors, and brokers. Establishes industry standards and advocates for real estate policies across NYC.
aliases: Real Estate Board of New York

definition: NYC Department of Transportation - issues over 150 different types of sidewalk and roadway construction permits to utilities, contractors, government agencies, and homeowners.

Qualified Exterior Wall Inspector - a Registered Architect or Professional Engineer certified by DOB to perform exterior wall inspections under the Facade Inspection & Safety Program (FISP/Local Law 11).

Owners must ensure gas meters remain in clean, dry locations free of refuse, at least 3 feet from hazards. Storage of combustibles prohibited within 5 feet. Natural gas piping is prone to leaks near meters.

A living room used for cooking with 80+ square feet of floor area, classifying it as habitable space requiring light and air. NYC kitchens must have proper ventilation, sink with running water, and fire-retarded materials.
Violations when plumbing systems fail to meet NYC Plumbing Code standards. Common causes: improper drain slopes, missing clean-outs, incorrect fittings or materials, inadequate fixture clearance.

A sign showing goods or services available somewhere other than where the sign is erected. Largely prohibited in NYC residential areas. Small non-commercial signs (up to 12 sq ft for Sale/Rent) are permitted.

Environmental Protection Agency - federal agency (not NYC) that shapes what property owners must do to protect air, water, and environmental health. Enforces lead-based paint violations, drinking water contamination, asbestos and pesticide mishandling. EPA requirements supersede local DEP and DOB rules.

Work Without a Permit - construction or alteration work performed without obtaining the necessary DOB permit. The most common violation type in NYC building code enforcement. Can result in fines, mandatory corrections, and additional penalties if hazardous conditions are present.

NYC DOB issues several certificate types: Certificate of Occupancy (CO) confirms code compliance; Temporary CO (TCO) permits occupancy while work is pending; Certificate of Compliance verifies equipment code compliance; Elevator and Boiler Certificates prove inspection compliance.
